question: Should all nuclear weapons be eliminated?

content.source_1: International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) — “Nuclear weapons: ending a threat to humanity” (policy position, 2022). Presents evidence that no state or international system could adequately respond to a nuclear detonation and that the only guarantee against catastrophic humanitarian harm is prohibition and elimination. https://www.icrc.org/en/document/nuclear-weapons-why-a-ban-is-necessary
content.source_2: NATO — “Strategic Concept” (adopted June 2022). Argues the opposing view that nuclear weapons remain the “supreme guarantee” of allies’ security and deterrence; as long as they exist, NATO will remain a nuclear alliance, implying abolition now would undermine stability. https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_196951.htm
content.source_3: National Research Council (U.S. National Academies) — “Monitoring Nuclear Weapons and Nuclear-Explosive Materials: An Assessment of Methods and Capabilities” (2005). Details the technical and verification challenges of confirming complete disarmament and detecting clandestine stockpiles or breakout, highlighting practical obstacles to safe elimination. https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/11265
content.source_4: Chatham House (Royal Institute of International Affairs) — “Too Close for Comfort: Cases of Near Nuclear Use and Options for Policy” (2014). Documents multiple near-miss incidents from false alarms and misinterpretation, evidencing persistent risks of accidental or inadvertent use that elimination would remove. https://www.chathamhouse.org/2014/04/too-close-comfort-cases-near-nuclear-use-and-options-policy
content.source_5: Xia, Lili et al. — “Global food insecurity and famine from reduced crop, marine fishery and livestock production due to climate disruption from nuclear war soot injection” (Nature Food, 2022). Uses modern climate–food system models to show even a regional nuclear war could trigger severe global food shortfalls with billions at risk, supporting elimination to avoid systemic climate-agricultural shocks. https://www.nature.com/articles/s43016-022-00573-0
content.source_6: Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) — Press release “Global Milestone Achieved: All Declared Chemical Weapons Stockpiles Destroyed” (7 July 2023). Provides a contrasting feasibility precedent: a WMD category has been verifiably eliminated under a robust treaty regime (CWC), suggesting abolition can be achieved when verification and compliance systems are strong. https://www.opcw.org/media-centre/news/2023/07/global-milestone-achieved-all-declared-chemical-weapons-stockpiles-destroyed
